Tuesday's primary elections in three states — Georgia, Kentucky, and Texas — feature three high-profile Democratic women on the ballot, including Stacey Abrams, who could become the first African-American women governor in U.S. history if she wins Georgia's gubernatorial race this November.

Zuckerberg appears before European Parliament over Facebook scandal

Fresh off testifying before Congress last month, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will appear before European Parliament to address how the social network will respond to the massive data scandal involving Cambridge Analytica.

(Photo: Shawn Thew, EPA-EFE)

Trump meets with Moon Jae-in ahead of scheduled summit with N. Korea

President Trump will meet with South Korean President Moon Jae-in at the White House Tuesday ahead of the scheduled historic summit with North Korea.

Moon, whose country's economy and peace hang on the June 12 summit, will likely tell Trump about his talk with North Korea leader Kim Jong Un last month when they met to discuss a possible peace agreement and denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula.

On Tuesday, Google will roll out YouTube Music, a streaming music service for $9.99 a month that will eventually replace Google Play Music, which has languished behind more popular services such as Spotify and Apple Music.

CLOSE With the summit between North Korea and the U.S. less than a month away, President Trump has been seeking the advice of aides and allies on whether or not he should move forward with the planned meeting.
Last week, North Korea threatened to call off the summit with Trump over perceived threats from the joint U.S.-South Korea military exercises and from Trump's national security adviser John Bolton.
Also on the ballot Tuesday: Laura Moser, who is running for Congress in Texas' seventh congressional district, and Amy McGrath, a former Marine running for Kentucky's 6th congressional district.
Antonio Tajani, president of European Parliament, confirmed that Zuckerberg has agreed to allow his address to be live-streamed, where he is expected to apologize for data breaches.
